SUMMARY:  LATE FILED. On March 15, 2016, Dennis Quinn, Chief Operating Officer of Joule Assets Inc. (Joule Assets), met with Cmmr. Peterman in San Francisco.  Also present were David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Mike Gordon, Chief Executive Officer of Joule Assets. Quinn provided an overview of Joule Assets and its role as manager of the Energy Reduction Asset (ERA) Fund, a private equity fund that invests in energy reduction solutions in small and medium commercial facilities, including energy efficiency.  Quinn highlighted the ERA Fund’s focus on performance-based solutions using M&V for each participating site. Quinn described how Joule Assets achieves deployment through development of a network of contractor and technology partners; incorporates best practices, such as ICP certification with its projects and incorporates investment-grade backed performance insurance for its portfolio of projects. Quinn noted that the ERA Fund is interested in investing in projects availing of the principles of both SB 350 and AB 802. Joule Assets stated that it has been actively involved in providing input as California Alternative Energy and Advanced Transportation Financing Authority develops credit enhancement programs to support further energy efficiency investment to meet the objectives of SB 350.  Quinn reinforced that timely measurement and verification and baseline methodology development will be key to AB 802 success. Quinn encouraged the Commission to let the market demonstrate that solutions exist today for success. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On March 16, 2016, Beckie Menten, Director of Customer Programs of Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Cmmr. Peterman in San Francisco.  Also present were David Gamson and Joanna Gubman, advisors to Cmmr. Peterman; and Shalini Swaroop, Regulatory and Legislative Counsel, for MCE.  Menten touched upon MCE’s recently filed Petition for Modification that requested an increase to its annual budget to account for MCE's inclusion of new communities. Menten noted that MCE's service territory grew 30% in 2015 and will likely see similar growth in 2016. Menten indicated that the EE Coordinating Committee is an impressive effort that merits a high level of engagement from all parties. Menten described the capacity challenges that are faced by small program administrators, and indicated that the staff of MCE may need to scale back engagement efforts with the EE Coordinating Committee. However, Menten did not believe this would cause concerns because as local government agencies, CCAs are already subject to a variety of rules related to transparency.  Menten voiced concerns on the methodology of ex ante review and indicated an open and transparent forum for saving estimate review offered by the Technical Forum would be a welcome change. Menten further emphasized having CPUC engagement early on in the process will improve both savings estimates and stakeholder engagement.

Menten touched upon MCE’s recently filed Petition for Modification that requested an increase to its annual budget to account for MCE's inclusion of new communities. Description: SUMMARY: on January 26, 2016, Donald Gilligan, President of the National Association of Energy Service Companies (ESCO) met with Cmmr. Peterman in San Francisco. SUMMARY:  On October 29, 2015, Terry Fry, Senior Vice President, Nexant, Inc. (Nexant), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present were Mushtaq Ahmad, Senior Manager, Milena Usabiaga, Project Manager, and Jack Stoddard, attorney, for Nexant.  At the meeting, Nexant briefed on a staff disposition that would deny energy efficiency savings claimed for a Nexant industrial retrocommissioning project. Nexant explained that air compressor projects represent significant energy efficiency savings potential, and it is not industry standard practice to repair air leaks in air compressor systems unless the air compressors are not meeting the customer's end use needs. Nextant further explained that Title 24 is not triggered in this instance and that Staff's characterization of the air compressor project as a "to code" project was incorrect.  Nextant also stated that it is prohibited from communicating directly with staff regarding errors in the disposition; and that because Nexant is a third party implementer, and not the Program Administrator, there is no clear process for it to appeal or seek review of the staff disposition.

SUMMARY:  On April 1, 2015, Anthony Harrison, Policy Director of the California Energy Efficiency Industry Council (Efficiency Council) met with Cmmr. Peterman.  Also present were Julie Fitch, Jennifer Kalafut and Melicia Charles, advisors to Cmmr. Peterman, and Ben Bodell, law student extern for Cmmr. Peterman; Jeanne Clinton, Governor's CPUC advisor on energy efficiency; and Steve Schiller, Board Chair Emeritus, for the Efficiency Council.  Efficiency Council's representatives discussed Assembly Bill 1330, a bill currently introduced in the  
California Legislature, which is sponsored by the Efficiency Council.  The Efficiency Council representatives explained that this legislation could work in conjunction with the goal setting process within the proceeding, as it simply establishes a "floor" by which energy savings through efficiency must be achieved.  Schiller explained that since energy efficiency is a resource that all Californians can benefit from, the Efficiency Council felt that it was important to ensure disadvantage communities were included in a major way in the state's energy efficiency efforts. A written material (attached to the notice) was used.
